identificationModule.briefTitle: Effect of Intensified Occupational Therapy on Basic Activities of Daily Living
identificationModule.officialTitle: Effect of Intensified Occupational Therapy on Basic Activities of Daily Living: a Randomized Controlled Trial

descriptionModule.briefSummary: The objective is to investigate the effect of an intensified occupational therapy intervention on independence in basic activities of daily living (ADL) in subjects with stroke

armGroups.label: Intensified occupational therapy
armGroups.description: Two hours occupational therapy each weekday with specific focus on basic ADL

armGroups.label: Usual care
armGroups.description: Occupational therapist instruct nursing staff on how to assist patients with basic ADL

interventions.name: Intensified occupational therapy
interventions.description: The intervention is an intensified occupational therapy effort, which does not take time away from other occupational therapy efforts.

primaryOutcomes.measure: Assessment of motor and process skills (AMPS)
primaryOutcomes.description: Observed limitations in activities of daily living, with scores for the motor- and proces- domains of activitites of daily living abilities. Each item in the domains is scored on a 4-point Likert scale, with higher scores representing a better outcome.
primaryOutcomes.timeFrame: Change in scores from baseline to scores following three weeks intervention

secondaryOutcomes.timeFrame: Change in scores from baseline to scores following three weeks intervention

secondaryOutcomes.description: FIM measures activities of daily living observed by the interdisciplinary team in routinely daily practice. The scale has 18 items which are scored on a 7 point Likert Scale. The total score thus range from 18 to 126, with higher scores represent a better outcome.
secondaryOutcomes.timeFrame: Change in scores from baseline to scores following three weeks intervention

secondaryOutcomes.description: Scoring system based on rehabilitation goal setting. Each rehabilitation goal is rated on a 5-point Likert scale from -2 to +2 with higher score representing a better outcome. Examples are: -2 denoting "much less than expected" and +2 denoting "much more than expected".
Length of stay starts the day the patient is admitted for subacute rehabilitation and ends the day the patient is discharged. The mean length of stay at the hospital is arround 6 weeks.
secondaryOutcomes.timeFrame: Follow-up up to one year of admission for inpatient rehabilitation.

eligibilityModule.eligibilityCriteria:
Inclusion Criteria:

* \<4 on four of six Functional Independence Measure (FIM) basic ADL items

Exclusion Criteria:

* Not able to understand danish
